docs.lead_paragraph: Despite lively opposition, Shell will start testing wells in northern Alaska, in a moment of major promise and considerable danger.

headline.seo: Shell Arctic Ocean Drilling Stands to Open New Oil Frontier
headline.main: New and Frozen Frontier Awaits Offshore Oil Drilling
headline.print_headline: Offshore Oil Drilling’s New and Frozen Frontier

docs.abstract: Shell, barring a successful last-minute legal challenge by environmental groups, will begin drilling test wells off the coast of northern Alaska in July, opening a new frontier in domestic oil exploration and accelerating a global rush to tap untold oil resources beneath the frozen ocean; Alaskan Arctic is viewed as the last great domestic oil prospect, but many natives and environmentalists say drilling threatens wildlife and shorelines (Series: The Energy Rush).
docs.snippet: Despite lively opposition, Shell will start testing wells in northern Alaska, in a moment of major promise and considerable danger.

byline.original: By JOHN M. BRODER and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers found that employer-provided insurance is likely to continue to be more generous even if the new health care law is upheld.

headline.seo: Many Individual Health Policies Fall Short, a Study Says
headline.main: Individual Health Policies Fall Short, a Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Individual Health Policies Fall Short, a Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study published in Health Affairs finds more than half of all medical insurance policies sold to individuals now fail to meet the standards of coverage set by the federal health care under review by the Supreme Court; concludes that even if the law is upheld, employer-provided insurance plans are likely to continue to be more generous.
docs.snippet: Researchers found that employer-provided insurance is likely to continue to be more generous even if the new health care law is upheld.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: More than half of all medical insurance policies sold to individuals now fail to meet the standards of coverage set by the federal health care law under review by the Supreme Court, a new study says. Even if the law is upheld, employer-provided insurance plans are likely to continue to be more generous, but the law would significantly improve the quality of coverage for individuals in several ways, the researchers concluded.

headline.main: Individual Health Policies Fall Short, a Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study published in Health Affairs finds more than half of all medical insurance policies sold to individuals now fail to meet the standards of coverage set by the federal health care under review by the Supreme Court; concludes that even if the law is upheld, employer-provided insurance plans are likely to continue to be more generous. (M)

headline.main: How Can We Bring Trust Back to Childbirth?

docs.abstract: The midwife Ina May Gaskin wins her clients' trust in a way that has become nearly impossible for most health care providers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The new health care law has improved the system for patients, and those gains will survive any Supreme Court decision, some Democratic officials said.

headline.seo: Gains in Health System Seen as Lasting by Some
headline.main: Gains in Health System Seen as Lasting by Some
headline.print_headline: Gains in Health System Seen as Lasting by Some

docs.abstract: Democratic officials say the new health care law is already transforming the way care is delivered, and the changes will continue regardless of how the Supreme Court rules on the mandate for most Americans to carry health insurance.
docs.snippet: The new health care law has improved the system for patients, and those gains will survive any Supreme Court decision, some Democratic officials said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, called Ms. Beckett “an inadvertent pioneer in the civil rights movement for people with disabilities.”

headline.seo: Katie Beckett, Who Inspired Health Reform, Dies at 34
headline.main: Katie Beckett, Who Inspired Health Reform, Dies at 34
headline.print_headline: Katie Beckett, 34; Inspired Shift on Care

docs.abstract: Katie Beckett, who became an inadvertent pioneer in the civil rights movement for people with disabilities and the inspiration for regulations that have allowed more than 500,000 disabled children to live at home since 1981, dies at age 34.
docs.snippet: Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, called Ms. Beckett “an inadvertent pioneer in the civil rights movement for people with disabilities.”

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama and Mitt Romney are making starkly different appeals that reflect the divergent ideologies and core constituencies of the two parties.

headline.seo: Presidential Race Pits Government Against Business
headline.main: In One Corner, a Champion of Government. In the Other, Its Foe.
headline.print_headline: In One Corner, a Champion of Government. In the Other, Its Foe.

docs.abstract: Political memo; Pres Obama and presumptive Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney are making starkly different appeals that reflect the divergent ideologies and core constituencies of the two parties; Obama champions the government as a linchpin of economic growth and protector of Americans, while Romney condemns government as a menace that imperils the free market's ability to enhance individual opportunity and make the nation prosperous.
docs.snippet: President Obama and Mitt Romney are making starkly different appeals that reflect the divergent ideologies and core constituencies of the two parties.

docs.lead_paragraph: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said the economy could contract 1.3 percent in the first half of 2013 if several big tax increases and spending cuts take effect.

headline.seo: Economy Could Tip Back Into Recession on Washington Impasse, Budget Office Says
headline.main: Recession Possible if Impasse Persists, Budget Office Says
headline.print_headline: Economy Could Tip Back Into Recession on Washington Impasse, Budget Office Says

docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office reports that the economy could relapse into a recession if Pres Obama and Congress remain at an impasse and allow several big tax increases and spending cuts to take effect at the start of 2013.
docs.snippet: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said the economy could contract 1.3 percent in the first half of 2013 if several big tax increases and spending cuts take effect.

headline.main: Obama vs. Catholics, Catholics vs. Obama

docs.abstract: Is the Obama administration’s dispute with Catholic institutions turning into a fight with American Catholicism as a culture?
